content.description:
An historic route, this one had an old cloth belt for an anchor. It's been upgraded.  

  Climb the crack. The crux is being crowded by the small trees.
content.location: Start behind a boulder on the left side of the Blueberry crack alcove.

content.description: The the low profile arete that roughly resembles an elephant's trunk. The climbing is good and although improbable I thought the gear was good and didn't feel run out.
content.location: Secret Garden, just right of The Growers Corner

content.description: To the left of "Hand Crack" is a crack/seam that runs to the tree cluster of "Hand Cracks" anchor.Climb to the start of "Hand Crack" and traverse left 15 feet to the start of the slabby seam. Honestly I thought it was a really fun route but have your head on tight because the gear is mostly really bad or non existent. It's really easy to set up a TR from the top of Hand Crack.
content.protection: Bring medium and small cams, micro offset nuts and tricams.
content.location: The route is 15 feet to the left of Hand Crack. Use the rapell anchor in the trees to get down.

content.description:
Start up the left side of the alcove, climb to the crack with no pro, follow it left stepping left to the tree anchor. 

  Alternately, climb past the tree and follow an easy crack/ramp back right to the blueberry crack anchor (100')
content.protection: Not the greatest but it's there. I'd say bring a single rack of cams to #1 the crack is shallow and irregular.

content.description:
This route is quite good but not a good intro to 5.9 trad climbing. Start on the route Diagonal 5.6 and follow that crack for about ten feet, from here balance and technique up the face above using obvious seems for protection. (In one vertical seam there is a perfect .75 pod that shows itself when it looks like it will take no more gear.) The crux of this route is the 15 feet of climbing after leaving Diagonal 5.6, with the hardest move being a awkward step left onto a small foot. 

  The route could use a good cleaning and might actually make it better and possibly a little easier.
content.protection: Standard rack, protection is a little awkward sometimes.
content.location: climb Diagonal 5.6 for ten feet the dance straight up the face to trees.

content.description: Climb a right slanting crack to a stance. Follow a short flaring  vertical crack placing a finger sized cam in a pocket at its top then make a thin move left to the tree anchor.
content.location: About twenty feet left of Trees-a-crowd. All alone.

content.description: Climb the slightly left arching hand size crack to the blocky left faceing corner and tree anchor. Pretty fun climb if your at Bryant and worth doing. The gear is good and plentiful thought the route. Still needs some cleaning as there is vegetation growing in the crack, but easy to avoid.
content.location: To the left of Diagonal and Millennium Falcon you can't miss it.

content.description: This is the right facing corner abutting the wild overhang in "The Secret Garden" The crux is down low, not protected, probably wet, and maybe not even 5.9. Kinda old school cool. Some years back my buddy Nick gave this a quick cleaning on rappel before leading the still very dirty crack. We lowered from some bushes and later retrieved our gear. You could also top out.
content.location: The steep wall left of Blueberry crack. This area has been called "The Secret Garden"

content.description:
Climbing doesn't always have to be hard.  

  Start up a a quartz dike with no pro (5.2), climb the crack to a ledge then a couple of short walls lead to a tree anchor.  

  Maybe bring some webbing to back up the chord anchor. Or step left to blueberry crack. Rap or lower off.
content.location: Same alcove start as blueberry crack.

content.description:
This is the most obvious line on the cliff. Start at the base of the obvious large Diagonal crack. The crux comes when passing a cluster of bushes that stick out of the crack. This route is interesting because the feet are small your legs will actually get pumped.  

  The route could use a bit of a cleaning, it has some lichen on some of the feet. If it got a nice cleaning it would deserve another star of sure.
content.protection: Standard rack, it does not take big gear like it looks like it will.
content.location: When you approach the cliff this is the first and most obvious line you will see. It is a lerge right trending Diagonal (hence the name).

content.description:
Just a really nice crack.  

  Climb straight up the slab gaining the vertical crack. The crux comes as the angle lessens but the crack seems out. Step left placing a #1 camalot then make your way to the trees.  

  Lower or rap off a tree anchor.
content.protection: A single rack of cams to #2 maybe some nuts.
content.location: Climbs just of left "Seeming" out of an alcove left and below the belay area for Diagonal. There's a weak trail down.

content.description:
[Updated and corrected Aug 2017 - R. Hall w/ permission of M Wallace, submitter]

 This is a little cliff located very close to the road in Woodstock NH. The cliff is about 100 feet tall at it highest point and has a general dome shape. There is evidence of climbing here but I don't not know the extent of it, but there are 3 or 4 trees with very old slings on them. [2017 update, we found newer slings with quick-links on at least 4 or 5 trees. R Hall] 

  The parking area for Bryant Ledge is small only 2 or 3 cars can fit there so if it is full please respect it and don't park in the driveway that approaches the house(s). However, if you decided to go here you will probably have the place to yourself so parking should never be an issue.
